entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud UM’s Event Log Archive and Deletion using SAP Job Scheduling Service
entry.content:
Hey everyone, Inspired by the job scheduler blogpost, Maximizing BTP Job Scheduling Service with SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model, I’d like to share with you one topic which can help administrators in archiving and deleting Event Logs from your tenants in a periodic way.

Before we talk about the periodic archiving and deletion of event logs, let us try to answer few questions that you may already have 

1) How much memory do Event Logs usually consume once they’re generated?
Based from personal experience within a test tenant, a logged event ranges between 150-350 bytes per record depending on trace information.

If you are interested in trying it on your tenant, below is an example sql syntax.

SELECT SCHEMA_NAME, TABLE_NAME, RECORD_COUNT,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_MAIN  AS MAIN_BYTES,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_DELTA AS DELTA_BYTES,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL AS TOTAL_BYTES,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_MAIN  / POWER(1024, 3), 5) AS MAIN_GB,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_DELTA / POWER(1024, 3), 5) AS DELTA_GB,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL / POWER(1024, 3), 5) AS TOTAL_GB,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL / RECORD_COUNT AS BYTES_PER_RECORD,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL/ RECORD_COUNT / POWER(1024, 3), 8) AS GB_PER_RECORD
FROM SYS.M_CS_TABLES
WHERE TABLE_NAME = 'SAP_ACE_EVENTLOGS';


2) When is the suggested time to do archiving? 
Based on scaling by statistics, it’s generally recommended to maintain around 60% available memory. This helps the system handle processing peaks more effectively and ensures a consistently responsive modeling experience.  For example, in a tenant with default 64GB memory, keeping approximately 38.4 GB available free memory provides optimal headroom for operations. See SAP PaPM Cloud Sizing Guide for more information. 

From hands on project experience, a team of three (3) experienced modelers building a sophisticated content in a development tenant will produce 4million event log entries in 3 months which is equivalent with 1GB of hugged memory.  
With such, in modeling activities we personally delete event logs every 3months or every 4million records, whichever comes first.  

Now the question is, How should we do this automatically? 

For every 4million records or every 1GB, you may check if SAP Cloud ALM has capabilities to notify you when your event logs reach this number. 

For every 3 months (periodic), this is then the focus of this blogpost. Let’s go ahead and see how we can utilize UM released API, Archive of Event Logs in combination with SAP Job Scheduler Service (JSS) to perform the event log cleanup. 


Prerequisite
You have gone through Phase I - SAP BTP: Application and Instance Subscriptions and Phase II - SAP BTP: Creation of Customized Application of blogpost, Maximizing BTP Job Scheduling Service with SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model

Procedure
1. Following Phase III - SAP PAPM Cloud UM: Collect API Action URL, Collect Archive Event Log (Action URL) which may come from the system itself by following the dev tools

or use Universal Model - Administration Service > /archive API.

URL will then look like:
<BTP Proxy Application Routes>/ace/<$batch's request url>/<$batch's payload>
https://jobscheduler-papm-proxy.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com /ace/sap/ace/AdministrationService/archive

2. Following Phase IV - SAP JSS: Job Creation, use the generated URL above in order to create the job.


3. Following Phase V - SAP JSS: Job Scheduling, users can a job or several jobs which can be executed in future time. For example, I wanted to delete the logs and create an archive every 5 minutes until end of the year. You can do it by creating a schedule like below:
Note: If in case you want to have this job available until future time e.g. 2028. You may change the olderthan json body value like 2028-12-31T16:43:37.



this will be executed and run logs for the job will have this execution information.

Usage of 5 minutes interval is used only for test purposes but in a real world you may opt to schedule this periodically every three months. You just need to check the proper scheduling value for it. See cron format for more info.

In the end, you will see in the system entry of archived event logs.


In addition, you will also have a cleaner event log list.


That’s all for now. Hope it helped you make use of another useful API which can be used in a scheduled manner in SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model. Until next time!

entry.title: Smooth Transition for your SAP PaPM Cloud UM containers with SAP Cloud Transport Management service
entry.content:
This blogpost walks you through how to use SAP Cloud Transport Management with the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud - Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM) in Manage Containers.

Why SAP Cloud Transport Management?

Pairing SAP Cloud Transport Management with SAP PaPM Cloud UM gives content managers a new dimension of flexibility. Instead of relying solely on the Manage Containers application, SAP Cloud Transport Management provides a more efficient, controlled, and secure approach to managing transports across tenants.

To dive deeper into what SAP Cloud Transport Management is and how it works, you can explore the SAP Cloud Transport Management documentation.

What Admins and Content Managers Need to Know

These are several important points to keep in mind:

  1. SAP Cloud Transport Management will not replace Manage Containers – Think of it as an additional transport option. You can choose the one that best fits your use case.
  2. SAP Cloud Transport Management is not bundled with SAP PaPM Cloud UM – It’s a separate license, so make sure to evaluate the entitlements before planning your transport strategy.
  3. One subscription can serve multiple subaccounts – A single SAP Cloud Transport Management subscription can be configured and linked to multiple SAP PaPM subaccounts.

In this example, I will create a three-node landscape and set up routes similar to what is commonly used in a real-world business scenario. It is common to work with at least three tenants for modeling purposes: Development, where ideas are first modeled, Quality Assurance (QA) to validate, and Production for business use. 

In Manage Containers, you will find the Release for Transport button. But before using it, SAP Cloud Transport Management must be properly configured in your SAP BTP subaccount. For step-by-step instructions and setup details, you can refer to our Admin Guide – SAP Cloud Transport Management.

There are four types of URL destinations available, and you can quickly copy them in the Administration Guide - URL.

Option 1: URL for Importing an Environment via Manage Containers

Option 2: URL for Uploading and/or Restoring Archived Demo Data via Manage Archives

Note: The environment should be activated to successfully restore demo data.

 

As I've mentioned above, I have created a three-node landscape and set up routes in SAP Cloud Transport Management.

  • The Development node serves solely as a virtual node and placeholder before a content transition to the succeeding node which in this case is the Quality Assurance (QA) node.
  • The Quality Assurance (QA) node uses an Activate URL (https://<PaPMServiceKey.url>/ace/sap/ace/tms/activate) which allows you to upload a container then import and activate the environment before moving to the Production node.
  • The Production node uses the Import URL (https://<PaPMServiceKey.url>/ace/sap/ace/tms/import) which allows you to upload a container and import it without activating the environment.

To create a transport object for transport, perform the following steps:

  1. Go to the Administration application group and choose the Manage Containers application.
  2. Select the desired container and choose Release for Transport.
  3. Select the transport node to be released and choose Release to Transport.
  4. The Transport Request number will be displayed on the screen.

 

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, the Transport Request will reflect allowing you to seamlessly move the container in the created transport nodes and routes.

  1. Go to SAP Cloud Transport Management application and choose Landscape Visualization.
  2. Choose the Development node and select Import Queue.
  3. Select the Transport Request and choose Import Selected.

 

After you have successfully imported the Transport Request to the Quality Assurance (QA) node, you may now start importing this container to the set destination tenant of this node by following the steps above, but this time in the Quality Assurance (QA) node.

 

In the SAP PaPM Cloud UM – Quality Assurance (QA) tenant, you can view the uploaded container in the Manage Containers and see it successfully imported and activated in Manage Environments application.

 

Going back to SAP Cloud Transport Management, the Transport Request has been successfully transitioned to the Production node and is ready to be imported to the set destination.

 

In the SAP PaPM Cloud UM – Production tenant, you can view the uploaded container in the Manage Containers application and see it successfully imported in Manage Environments application. 

 

Now that you understand how to use SAP Cloud Transport Management service to transition your environment across SAP PaPM Cloud UM tenants, you can confidently streamline your transport process with improved control, traceability, and efficiency. This ensures that your models move seamlessly and securely from Development to Production.

 

Happy transporting! 🚀

Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements!

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model - Introducing Release Cadence Settings
entry.content:
Dear Administrators, 

You may have already noticed some exciting additions to the Administration Settings panel over the past few months. Today, we are pleased to introduce a powerful new feature designed to give you more flexibility and control over how updates for SAP Profitability and Performance Management - Standard Model are delivered to you: Fast Track mode. 

What is Fast Track Mode? 

Have you ever wished you could access the latest SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud - Standard Model (referred to as SAP PaPM Cloud SM hereon) features earlier — before they are rolled out globally across all tenants? 

With Fast Track Mode, this is now possible. 

By simply activating the Fast Track mode toggle in the Administration Settings, your selected tenant will immediately begin receiving more frequent updates for SAP PaPM Cloud SM. This includes early access to new functionalities and improvements—ideal for your development and quality assurance environments where early testing is beneficial. 

 

What’s the Default Behavior? 

By default, Fast Track Mode is deactivated, meaning your tenant will receive updates of SAP PaPM Cloud SM only once per month, specifically on the second Monday of the month. So, the default release cadence for such updates is monthly.

However, the same updates become available a few weeks earlier for tenants where Fast Track mode is activated. This provides a valuable window to test changes in advance and ensure everything is working perfectly with your specific business scenarios. 

Note: Given that we are gradually rolling this feature out across all regions, latest by 1 Nov 2025 all the tenants will be moved to the default release cadence - meaning, Fast Track mode will be in deactivated state for everyone. Administrators will have the option to activate Fast Track mode for themselves using the toggle as described earlier.


How to Activate or Deactivate Fast Track Mode? 

Activating Fast Track mode is straightforward: 

  • Navigate to Administration Settings.

  • Activate the Fast Track mode toggle. 

The change takes effect immediately. 

Need to revert to the default release cadence? No problem. Simply switch off the toggle. Please note that reverting may require waiting until the next monthly release (i.e., next month). 

We hope this new option helps you make the most of your multiple SAP PaPM Cloud SM tenants. Stay tuned—more updates and tips are coming your way!
